comment._content: Yes juilong, it is definitely Middle Head, but I think a couple of hundred metres to the north from the 'normal' group of gun emplacements in your photo, because of the black headland on the right of the cannon in the photo. Field trip required!  Can anyone date the uniform?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: The black headland at the right of the cannon in the photo is not actually a headland. It is an earthen berm which was created to correct a design fault which would have permitted adjacent cannon to fire upon one another without the presence of the berm. This problem was only recognised after the construction of the emplacements and installation of the guns. I've taken two photographs of emplacements nearby, but not this one: www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy/2911023023/ www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy/2909598486/in/photostream/ Not that I can precisely identify this cannon, but I've seen lots of photographs of cannon around Sydney in the 1880 to 1910 period, and this is one of the clearest photographs I've ever seen. That's the wonder of lifting the image from a well preserved glass plate negative.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
A BERM ?!

I just had an Inspector Clouseau moment !  

Thanks lifeasdaddy.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Yet another Tom Roberts coincidence, from the Australian War Memorial website: cas.awm.gov.au/PROD/cas_disp_pkg.pr_detailed_scr?surl=434... "Tom Roberts established 'Curlew camp" at Sirius Cove in Mosman by the end of the 1890s. While camped there, concentrating on painting outdoors, Roberts was commissioned to paint three works depicting the New South Wales military forces, commanded by his friend, Major General Edward Thomas Hutton, from 1893 - 1896" Could this photo be a study for one of the paintings?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And this Tom Roberts 1896 painting for uniform comparison (infantry not artillery): cas.awm.gov.au/PROD/cas_disp_pkg.pr_detailed_scr?surl=434... The man in the photo is perhaps there for scale, that is why he is not in full uniform as for a portrait, Those 10 inch Rifled Muzzle Loading guns were enormous, and at the time (1890s) being replaced by lighter and more efficient artillery. There are more photos of these guns being moved by men in similar dress (white pith helmets) on the AWM website - I cannot get the links to work. Type "10 inch RML" into their search engine. I am sure the Australian War Memorial would like to know about this photo - it is a much better quality than any they have.

comment.author: 99028520@N00
comment._content: This is a special type of mounting known as an Armstrong protected barbette mounting. One of these, a 10-inch RML ,was mounted in Fort Glanville www.communitywebs.org/FortGlanville/Fort_Glanville.htm You will find a photo in the gallery and others can still be found in Tangiers. farm1.static.flickr.com/77/169453964_4bf9b645dc.jpg Only one was mounted in the U.K. at Puckpool Battery.

comment.author: 21726514@N02
comment._content:
The gun at top is an RML 10-inch 25 ton gun - 2 were bought from Elswick Ordnance. 
They were mounted at Outer Middle Head, where they covered both eastward out to sea between the Heads and southeast covering the entrance to the harbour. It appears to be pointing eastward out to sea, so the caption is incorrect. I think the land in right background across the water is inner South Head.
They had a muzzle velocity of 1,976 ft/second, compared to the standard British army & navy 10-inch 18 ton gun with a mv of 1379 ft/second. Presumably the heavier construction allowed more powder & a longer barrel (21 ft 8 inch vs 15 feet), which together gave a high mv. These could have blown anything clean away if they hit it.

comment.author: 21726514@N02
comment._content: There were supposed to be two positions for these 10-inch 25 ton guns, identifiable by the semi-circular track for the carriage. Google Earth (maps.google.com/maps?q=-33.827169,151.267855&ll=-33.8...) only shows one such mounting today, and appears to face northeast, whereas the gun in our photo appears to face east. This photo at the AWM, from 1893, appears to show the lefthand gun in the mounting still visible on Google Earth, seems to match BeachcomberAustralia's photo : upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e5/RML_10_inch_g... Also - the photo above by BeachcomberAustralia (www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/3364384873/) does not appear to match our photo - the opening in the bottom of the wall at right (for loading ?) is absent in the period photo. I wonder whether the position in our period photo loaded from the left (i.e. was to the right of the position in BeachcomberAustralia's photo, on the other side of the magazine), and no longer exists ? I think the gun position in our picture was the righthand gun and was about here (maps.google.com/maps?q=-33.827169,151.267855&ll=-33.8...) but is long since demolished and replaced by a (6-inch ?) mounting of WWII vintage.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/dougthebear] Yes, that is Manly in the distance of that photo. Which only 'works' from Middle Head, rather than the Georges Head or Georges Heights batteries. Trove has got more inclusive since I last looked this up and I found these articles relevant and of interest - Description of "Our Fortifications" including this gun in 1885 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71023441
" ... At Middle Head there are two forts, the "outer" and the "inner". In the former are seven guns, all muzzle-loaders ; four 80-pounders, of 6in calibre, rifled with three grooves ; one 18 ton rifled Armstrong, muzzle-loading, rifled with seven grooves, fitted with patent hydraulic buffers; and two 25-ton Armstrongs, rifled on the Woolwich system, with 19 grooves, and fitted with Elswick compression plates. These latter are perfect models -- "regular beauties" our guide, the bombardier; calls them -- and are loaded and cleaned by machinery ; the loading being performed completely under cover, and the machinery being so delicately adjusted that one man can train and another elevate these "infants". The penetrative power of the "pills" dispensed from these patterns, from the widely-celebrated Armstrong Works, in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, is something impressive. Those pills can penetrate through a wrought-iron armour plate 18 inches in thickness, their effective range being with 12 degrees of elevation, 8200 yards. All these guns are mounted en barbette, and so placed that the traverse of one gun overlaps that of the others. The 80-pounders command the harbour from George's Head to Hornby Light, the Armstrong sweeping the entrance from Watson's Bay to Clontarf. ... ... "
Also the guns arriving (one sank!) in 1882 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70967871 And the AWM pictures of 1893 the 10 month "Long Course" when (I think) the guns were removed - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71219166 So this gun was a 10-inch Rifled Muzzle Loading (RML) 25-ton Armstrong, at the Outer Middle Head defences before 1893. Phew!

comment.author: 38293973@N08
comment._content: This book contains some good information on these guns, and how the British didn't even buy them, that the loading mechanism was overly complicated and how, as sold to the colony of NSW the mechanism that was meant to deal with the recoil was not up to the task. www.gould.com.au/Fragile-Forts-Fixed-Defences-p/amh026.htm The information quoted above was so much hype. The guns fired one round every three minutes, that is, one round in the the time it took a ship at the time to travel 800 metres or so at around 12 knots. In other words, they would have got off only two or three shots off between the time that the target came into view coming around the heads and the ship getting close enough so the guns could not depress far enough to be effective. As naval and coastal gunnery generally requires a number of aiming rounds before hits are achieved, the guns would have been quite useless and more for propaganda value to appease the concerns of the populace. In similar ways the three guns in the tower at Fort Dennison were unable to traverse, meaning that they could only shoot at a target that actually presented itself to them. The government could claim though that the harbour was defended by the guns of Fort Dennison though. The gun on the top of the tower was the only effective gun at Pinchgut.

comment.author: 38293973@N08
comment._content: I went out to Steel Point near Vaucluse yesterday.  The Two 68pbr SBML / 80pdr RML pits are in good condition.  One has been filled in with soil, but that is okay, the other can be walked and crawld over very nicely.  If I had the spare cash, and who knows what the future may bring, I would sponsor the installation of one of the 80pdr RML currently lying in the dirt at Middle Head on a replica carriage at Steel Point.  Would be a wonderful bonus for the Eastern suburbs.
